context: -cyclodextrin, cellulose, micropollutants, remediation, water treatmentINTRODUCTIONHumans introduce thousands of organic compounds, known asmicropollutants (MPs) when present at trace concentrations,into ground and surface waters.1These MPs are substancesused in agriculture, manufacturing, medicine, and other humanactivities.2Several studies have demonstrated that exposure toMPs may negatively in fluence both human health and aquaticecosystems.3,4For example, the presence of bisphenol A(BPA), a suspected endocrine disruptor used to make plasticsand epoxy resins, has raised concerns in human health becauseit can produce adverse e ffects in mammary glands and theimmune system at concentrations below its acute toxicitylevels.5Some polar and semipolar MPs are stable and persistent inthe environment, while others undergo biotic or abiotictransformation to form products that are persistent in water attrace concentrations, because they are only partially removedin conventional water treatment processes.6Therefore,enhanced treatments such as advanced oxidation, ultra-filtration, and adsorption are expected to play a role in MPremoval, especially as the health and ecological e ffects of MPsare better understood.710Adsorption is a widely applicabletechnique because it can remove contaminants withoutintroducing degradation byproducts,11and thus the scienti ficcommunity has explored numerous materials for adsorption ofcontaminants in water.12,13The performance of suchadsorbents has been evaluated in batch and/or packed-bedadsorption con figurations.14,15Remediation of ground andReceived: December 19, 2018Accepted: February 4, 2019Published: February 4,

context: Metal Organic Frameworks (MOFs) as ExceptionalMaterials for Water RemediationIn recent years, numerous studies have considered newprocesses to eliminate EOCs from water (i.e., ozonization,20chlorination,21sonodegradation,22biodegradation,23inorganicheterogeneous catalysis,24activated carbon treatment).25Among these technologies, metal organic frameworks(MOFs) have been recently investigated for the removal ofcontaminants in water.26MOFs are regarded as a novel class ofporous coordination polymers, comprising inorganic nodes(e.g., atoms, clusters, chains) and organic linkers (e.g.,carboxylates, phosphonates, azolates) that assemble intomultidimensional periodic lattices.27These materials havebeen proposed for diverse applications, including adsorption,28separation,29sensing,30catalysis,31fuel cells,32drug delivery,33light harvesting,34photocatalysis,35biocatalysis,36etc. MOFs arepromising materials for the elimination of contaminants sincethey present many properties that commend them in watertreatment: (i) large speci fic surface area and pore volume,associated with high sorption capacities, (ii) active sites, wherecontaminants can be chemisorb and/or degraded; (iii) some arehighly stable in water; (iv) easily functionalizable cavities, wherespecific hostguest interactions may take place; (v) oppor-tunities for tailoring MOFs structure to allow shape-selectiveadsorption and/or catalysis;31(vi) MOFs can be synthesized atlarge scale; and (vii) they can be shaped as monoliths, pellets,membranes, or columns, adapted for decontamination devices.
